comments.raw_text:
I saw the PC version of about:home and was struck by how large the font size of the snippets is...it throws the page off-balance and gives way too much weight to the snippets in relation to the search box. 

As a marketing guy, I'm all for making the snippets noticeable, but as a brand guy I wouldn't want anyone to think that we're prioritizing a promotional message over the usability of the page.

For the record, I am *definitely* not suggesting that this be any sort of Fx4 blocker, but we really should address this in the earliest possible .x release.

Thanks!
comments.creator: jslater@mozilla.com

comments.raw_text:
(In reply to comment #2)

> Here's the Mac version...much, much better.

Hmm. The styling is the same for Windows and OS X, and DOM Inspector claims the computed font-size on each is 13.6px. And comparing the first letter of each screenshot's snippet confirms that ("W" on Windows, "F" on OS X). A lowercase "e" on each is 8 pixels (exactly on Windows, 8-9 with OS X's antialiasing).

Is this just an illusion due to the slightly different font rendering? Also note that your Windows screenshot appears to be a differently sized window and different snippet, so it's 4 lines instead of 2.

Still a legit concern, illusion or not. (But would be good to do apples-to-apples comparison). A couple of things that could be done:

1) Add Windows-specific styling to make the font smaller so it looks right, math be damned. (Might need to be version-specific, Windows Vista+ has nicer font rendering).

2) Adjust the font size, for all platforms, based on window size. We already do a bit of this on the page. The text looks reasonable to me on Windows with a large browser window, but with small window the text is indeed a large fraction of the available space.
